data.que: What triggered the 1857 uprising in India?
data.ans: A variety of grievances including military, political, economic, and social causes; the immediate spark was the cartridge controversy in the army.

data.que: Who was Bahadur Shah Zafar?
data.ans: The last Mughal emperor who became a symbolic leader of the 1857 revolt.

data.que: What was the Indian National Congress (INC)?
data.ans: A political organization founded in 1885 to voice Indian demands and work for self-government.

data.que: Name two early leaders of the INC.
data.ans: Dadabhai Naoroji and Gopal Krishna Gokhale.

data.que: What did the Swadeshi movement promote?
data.ans: Boycott of British goods and promotion of indigenous industries and goods.

data.que: Who started the Non-Cooperation Movement?
data.ans: Mahatma Gandhi in 1920 as a mass movement against British rule.

data.que: What was the Rowlatt Act?
data.ans: A 1919 law allowing detention without trial, which led to widespread protests.

data.que: What happened at Jallianwala Bagh?
data.ans: In 1919 British troops fired on unarmed civilians gathered in Amritsar, killing many.

data.que: Who led the Salt Satyagraha (Dandi March)?
data.ans: Mahatma Gandhi in 1930 to protest the salt tax.

data.que: What was the demand in the Quit India Movement?
data.ans: Immediate British withdrawal from India (launched in 1942).

data.que: Define Satyagraha.
data.ans: A policy of nonviolent resistance or civil disobedience championed by Gandhi.

data.que: What was the role of women in the freedom movement?
data.ans: Women participated in protests, marches, and leadership roles, e.g., Sarojini Naidu.

data.que: Who was Subhas Chandra Bose?
data.ans: A radical nationalist leader who sought armed struggle and led the Indian National Army (INA).

data.que: What was the significance of the Lucknow Pact?
data.ans: An agreement (1916) between Congress and the Muslim League on joint demands and separate electorates.

data.que: What was the objective of the Home Rule Movement?
data.ans: To demand self-governance within the British Empire, led by Tilak and Annie Besant.

data.que: Name an economic impact of British colonialism on India.
data.ans: Deindustrialization of traditional industries and drain of wealth to Britain.

data.que: What was the Simon Commission?
data.ans: A 1927 British commission to review constitutional reform that excluded Indian members and faced protests.

data.que: Why did the Khilafat Movement ally with Congress?
data.ans: Shared anti-British goals and to build Hindu-Muslim unity after World War I.

data.que: What was the impact of World War I on Indian nationalism?
data.ans: It raised political expectations and economic strain, leading to increased demands for self-rule.

data.que: What is communalism in the Indian context?
data.ans: Political mobilization along religious lines, often leading to division between communities.

data.que: Who were moderate and extremist leaders in INC?
data.ans: Moderates sought gradual reform (e.g., Gokhale); extremists wanted direct action (e.g., Tilak).

data.que: How did the partition of Bengal (1905) affect nationalism?
data.ans: It sparked the Swadeshi movement and intensified anti-colonial activism.

data.que: What role did peasants play in the freedom movement?
data.ans: They participated in protests and local movements, sometimes driven by economic grievances.

data.que: What was the Cabinet Mission Plan (1946)?
data.ans: A British proposal to transfer power and create a federal arrangement in India; ultimately failed to prevent partition.

data.que: Name one reason for the rise of communal politics before independence.
data.ans: Colonial policies, separate electorates, and competing political aspirations among communities.

data.que: What is civil disobedience?
data.ans: Deliberate and public refusal to obey unjust laws as a form of protest.

data.que: Who wrote 'Poverty and Un-British Rule in India'?
data.ans: Dadabhai Naoroji (book highlighted economic exploitation).

data.que: What was the significance of the Cripps Mission (1942)?
data.ans: A failed British attempt to secure Indian cooperation in WWII by promising future dominion status.
